importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the public backlash and musician's objection to Trump's video were most actively reported and discussed.
The date when The White Stripes dropped their copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump, signaling a shift in legal actions related to political use of music.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the 'No Kings' protests took place and the AI-generated video was posted, marking the peak of political and public reaction.

keyTakeAways: Kenny Loggins, a singer-songwriter, has formally objected to the unauthorized use of his song 'Danger Zone' in a fake video created by AI and posted by President Trump on Truth Social.

The video features Trump in a fighter jet with the message 'KING TRUMP' and includes Loggins' performance of 'Danger Zone' as background music, showing a fictional scene of a plane dumping sludge over protest crowds in Times Square.

Loggins claims no permission was given for the use of his performance and requests its immediate removal, stating that the video is designed to divide people and undermines unity in a patriotic context.

The use of copyrighted music in political media is generally legal if proper licensing occurs, but performers can prohibit specific uses such as in campaign ads; however, public objections often serve as a moral or political statement.

Multiple artists and music estates, including The White Stripes and the estate of Isaac Hayes, have previously filed lawsuits against Trump over the use of their music in political content, though The White Stripes have dropped their suit and Hayes' case is still ongoing.
The White House did not respond directly to Loggins' request, instead sharing a promotional image from the film 'Top Gun' with the caption 'I FEEL THE NEED FOR SPEED'.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump

namedEntities.name: Danger Zone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The song performed by Kenny Loggins is central to the controversy, as its use in the AI video is contested and objected to by the artist.

namedEntities.name: Giorgio Moroder
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Co-writer of 'Danger Zone', contributing to the song's legal and artistic background, though the performance is attributed to Loggins.

namedEntities.name: Tom Whitlock
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Co-writer of 'Danger Zone', contributing to the song's composition and copyright status.

namedEntities.name: The White Stripes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump, which was dropped in November 2024, illustrating a broader pattern of artist opposition to political use of music.

namedEntities.name: Isaac Hayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His estate filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Trump and his reelection campaign, indicating a sustained legal effort by artists to protect their work from political appropriation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Singer-songwriter Kenny Loggins has requested that President Donald Trump remove the use of his performance of 'Danger Zone' from an AI-generated video posted on Truth Social. The video, depicting Trump in a fighter jet labeled 'KING TRUMP' dumping sludge over protest crowds in Times Square, was created in response to widespread 'No Kings' protests. Loggins claims the use of his song is unauthorized and harmful, as it promotes division rather than unity. While such use of copyrighted music is generally legal with proper licensing, performers can prohibit specific uses, especially in political contexts. This incident follows a history of artist lawsuits against Trump, including those by The White Stripes and the estate of Isaac Hayes, with the Hayes case still ongoing. The White House did not respond directly to Logginsâ€™ request, instead sharing a promotional image from the film 'Top Gun'.
title: Trump's fake video featured 'Danger Zone.' Musician Kenny Loggins wants it scrubbed
